STATIC_text.text:
The exercises that follow are designed to help you learn the terms presented in the chapter. Writing terms over and over again is a good way to study this new language. As you check each answer, you not only will reinforce your understanding of a term but often will gain additional information from the answer.

Each exercise is designed not as a test, but rather as an opportunity for you to learn the material.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Word beginnings are called [prefixes].

2. Word endings are called [suffixes].

3. The foundation of a word is known as the [root].

4. A letter linking a suffix and a root, or linking two roots, in a term is the [combining vowel].

5. The combination of a root and a combining vowel is known as the [combining form].

1. cardi/o [heart]

2. aden/o [gland]

3. bi/o [life]

4. cerebr/o [cerebrum/largest part of the brain]

5. cephal/o [head]

6. arthr/o [joint]

7. carcin/o [cancer/cancerous]

8. cyst/o [urinary bladder]

9. cyt/o [cell]

10. derm/o or dermat/o [skin]

11. encephal/o [brain]

12. electr/o [electricity]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following combining forms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. -oma [tumor/mass/swelling]

2. -al [pertaining to]

3. -itis [inflammation]

4. -logy [process of study]

5. -scopy [process of visual examination]

6. -ic [pertaining to]

7. -gram [record/image]

8. -opsy [process of viewing]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following suffixes.

questionContent.questionText:
1. cerebral [cerebr*/al]
2. biopsy [bi*/opsy]
3. adenitis [aden*/itis]
4. cephalic [cephal*/ic]
5. carcinoma [carcin*/oma]
6. cystoscopy [cyst*/o*/scopy]
7. electrocardiogram [electr*/o*/cardi*/o*/gram]
8. cardiology [cardi*/o*/logy]
9. electroencephalogram [electr*/o*/encephal*/o*/gram]
10. dermatitis [dermat*/itis]
11. arthroscopy [arthr*/o*/scopy]
12. cytology [cyt*/o*/logy]

instructions.instructions: Using slashes, divide the following terms into parts.

readingPart.reading: pertaining to the cerebrum, or largest part of the brain
process of viewing life (removal of living tissue and viewing it under a microscope)
inflammation of a gland
pertaining to the head
tumor that is cancerous (cancerous tumor)
process of visually examining the urinary bladder
record of the electricity in the heart
process of study of the heart
record of the electricity in the brain
inflammation of the skin
process of visual examination of a joint
process of study of cells

instructions.instructions: Give the meaning of the entire term.

questionContent.questionText:
1. erythr/o [red]

2. enter/o [intestines/small intestine/small intestines]

3. gastr/o [stomach]

4. gnos/o [knowledge]

5. hemat/o [blood]

6. cis/o [to cut]

7. nephr/o [kidney]

8. leuk/o [white]

9. iatr/o [treatment/physician]

10. hepat/o [liver]

11. neur/o [nerve]

12. gynec/o [woman/female]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following combining forms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. white blood cell: [leuko]cyte

2. inﬂammation of the stomach: gastr[itis]

3. pertaining to being produced by treatment: [iatro]genic

4. study of kidneys: [nephro]logy

5. red blood cell: [erythro]cyte

6. mass of blood: [hemat]oma

7. process of viewing living tissue (using a microscope): bi[opsy]

8. pain of nerves: neur[algia]

9. process of visual examination of the eye: [ophthalmo]scopy

10. inﬂammation of the small intestine: [enter]itis

instructions.instructions: Complete the medical term, based on its meaning as provided.

readingPart.reading:
onc/opath/oren/osect/o
ophthalm/opsych/orhin/othromb/o
oste/oradi/osarc/our/o

questionContent.questionText:
English Term

1. kidney [ren*/o]

2. disease [path*/o]

3. eye [ophthalm*/o]

4. to cut [sect*/o]

5. nose [rhin*/o]

6. ﬂesh  [sarc*/o]

7. mind [psych*/o]

8. urinary tract [ur*/o]

9. bone [oste*/o]

10. x-rays [radi*/o]

11. clotting [thromb*/o]

12. tumor [onc*/o]

instructions.instructions: Select from the combining forms below to match the numbered English terms. Write the correct combining form in the space provided.

questionContent.questionText:
1. process of visual examination of the eye: ophthalmo[scopy/scope/ectomy/tomy/tion]
2. instrument to visually examine the eye: ophthalmo[scope/scopy/ectomy/tomy/tion]
3. study of tumors: onco[logy/al/cyte/genic]
4. inflammation of bone: oste[itis/osis/oma]
5. abnormal condition of the mind: psych[osis/itis/oma]
6. clotting cell (platelet): thrombo[cyte/logy/al/genic]
7. pertaining to the kidney: ren[al/logy/cyte/genic]
8. removal (excision or resection) of the kidney: nephr[ectomy/scopy/scope/tomy/tion]
9. incision of (process of cutting into) a bone: osteo[tomy/scopy/scope/ectomy/tion]
10. process of cutting back (in the sense of “cutting out” or removal): resect[ion/scopy/scope/ectomy/tion/tomy]
11. pertaining to producing cancer: carcino[genic/logy/al/cyte]
12. tumor of flesh tissue (cancerous tumor found in connective tissue such as bone, fat and muscle): sarc[oma/itis/osis]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the suffix that best completes the described term.

questionContent.questionText:
Sufﬁx

1.-algia [pain]

2. -ion [process]

3. -emia [blood condition]

4. -gram [record (image)]

5. -scope  [instrument to visually examine]

6. -osis [condition, usually abnormal]

7. -ectomy [excision, removal (resection)]

8.-genic [pertaining to producing, produced by, or produced in]

9. -pathy [disease condition]

10. -tomy [process of cutting, incision]

11. -itis [inﬂammation]

12. -cyte [cell]

13. -globin [protein]

instructions.instructions: Match the sufﬁx with its meaning. Select the correct meaning from the dropdown.

readingPart.reading:
arthralgiaendocrineiatrogenic
carcinogenicexocrineleukemia
cystitishematomaleukocytosis
encephalopathyhepatoma (hepatocellular carcinoma)neuralgia

questionContent.questionText:
1. When Paul smoked cigarettes, he inhaled a [carcinogenic] substance with each puff.

2. Sally’s sore throat, fever, and chills made her doctor order a white blood cell count. The results, indicating infection, showed a slight increase in normal cells, a condition called [leukocytosis].

3. Mr. Smith’s liver enlarged, giving him abdominal pain. His radiologic tests and biopsy revealed a malignant tumor, or [hepatoma].

4. Mrs. Rose complained of pain in her hip joints, knees, and shoulders each morning. She was told that she had painful joints, or [arthralgia].

5. Dr. Black was trained to treat disorders of the pancreas, thyroid gland, adrenal glands, and pituitary gland. Thus, he was an expert in the [endocrine] glands.

6. Ms. Walsh told her doctor she had pain when urinating. After tests, the doctor’s  diagnosis was inﬂammation of the urinary bladder, or [cystitis].

7. Elizabeth’ s  overhead tennis shot hit David in the thigh, producing a large [hematoma]. His skin looked bruised and the affected area was tender.

8. Mr. Bell’ s  white blood cell count is 10 times higher than normal. Examination of his blood shows cancerous white blood cells. His diagnosis is [leukemia].

9. Mr. Kay was resuscitated (revived from potential or apparent death) in the emergency department after experiencing a heart attack. Unfortunately, he suffered a broken rib as a result of the   physician’s  chest compressions. This is an example of a/an [iatrogenic] fracture.

10. After playing one season for a professional football team, Bill Smith decided to retire because he worried about the dangers of concussions and head trauma—a condition called CTE, or chronic traumatic [encephalopathy].

instructions.instructions: Select from the listed terms to complete the sentences that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. dia- [complete/through]

2. pro- [before]

3. aut-, auto- [self/own]

4. a-, an- [no/not/without]

5. hyper- [excessive/above/more than normal]

6. hypo- [deficient/below/less than normal]

7. epi- [above/upon]

8. endo- [within]

9. retro- [behind]

10. trans- [across/through]

11. peri- [surrounding]

12. ex-, exo- [out]

13. sub- [below/under]

14. re- [back]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following preﬁxes

questionContent.questionText:
1. complete knowledge; a decision about the nature of the patient’s condition after the appropriate tests are done: [dia/pro/an]gnosis
2. before knowledge; a prediction about the outcome of treatment, given after the diagnosis: [pro/dia/an]gnosis
3. pertaining to below the liver: [sub/epi/peri/hyper/hypo]hepatic
4. the membrane surrounding the heart: [peri/sub/peri/hyper/hypo/epi]cardium
5. condition of excessive sugar in the blood: [hyper/sub/peri/epi/hypo]glycemia
6. pertaining to under the skin: [hypo/sub/peri/epi/hyper]dermic
7. pertaining to above the stomach: [epi/sub/peri/hyper/hypo]gastric
8. process of cutting back (in the sense of cutting out): [re/an/dia]section
9. condition of deficient (low) sugar in the blood: [hypo/sub/peri/epi/hyper]glycemia
10.condition of low numbers of erythrocytes (red blood cells) or deficient hemoglobin in these cells:
[an/dia/pro]emia

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the prefix that best completes the described term.

questionContent.questionText:
1. study of the urinary tract: [uro]logy

2. study of women and women’s diseases: [gyneco]logy

3. study of blood: [hemato]logy

4. study of tumors: [onco]logy

5. study of the kidneys: [nephro]logy

6. study of nerves: [neuro]logy

7. treatment of children: [ped]iatrics

8. study of x-rays in diagnostic imaging: [radio]logy

9. study of the eyes: [ophthalmo]logy

10. study of the stomach and intestines: [gastroentero]logy

11. study of glands that secrete hormones: [endocrino]logy

12. treatment of the mind: [psych]iatry

13. study of disease: [patho]logy

14. study of the heart: [cardio]logy

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms (describing areas of medicine), based on their meanings as given.

questionContent.questionText:
1. cerebrovascular accident [cerebrum] 
2. encephalitis [brain]
3. cystoscope [urinary bladder]
4. transhepatic [across/through]
5. osteogenic sarcoma [flesh]
6. hypogastric [under/below/deficient]
7. endocrine glands [within]
8. nephrectomy [excision/resection]
9. exocrine glands [outside]
10. neuralgia [pain]

instructions.instructions: Give the meaning of the underlined word part

readingPart.reading: A cerebrovascular accident, or stroke, is damage to the blood vessels of the cerebrum, leading to death of brain cells.
Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain.
A cystoscope is an instrument used to visually examine the urinary bladder. The cystoscope is inserted into the urethra and urinary bladder.
Transhepatic means pertaining to across or through the liver.
Osteogenic sarcoma is a malignant (cancerous) tumor originating in bone, which is considered a fleshy (connective) tissue of the body.
Hypogastric means pertaining to below the stomach.
Endocrine glands secrete hormones within the body. Examples of these are the pituitary, thyroid, and adrenal glands.
Nephrectomy is the removal of a kidney.
Exocrine glands secrete chemicals to the outside of the body. Examples are the sweat, lacrimal or tear-producing, prostate, and salivary glands.
Neuralgia is nerve pain.

anemiaoncogenicpsychiatrist
biopsyoncologistpsychologist
diagnosisosteoarthritisthrombocyte
leukemiapathogenicthrombosis
nephrologistprognosisurologist
neuropathy

questionContent.questionText:
1. Pamela Crick is 72 years old and suffers from a degenerative joint disease that is caused by the wearing away of tissue around her joints. This disease, which literally means “inﬂammation of bones and joints,” is [osteoarthritis].

2. The [biopsy] sample was removed during surgery and sent to a pathologist to be examined under a microscope for a proper diagnosis.

3. A/An [urologist] performed surgery to remove Mr. Simon’s cancerous kidney.

4. Ms. Rose has suffered from diabetes with hyperglycemia for many years. This condition can lead to long-term complications, such as the disease of nerves called diabetic [neuropathy].

5. A virus or a bacterium produces disease and is therefore a/an [pathogenic] organism.

6. Jordan has a disease caused by abnormal hemoglobin in his erythrocytes. The erythrocytes change shape, collapsing to form sickle-shaped cells that can become clots and stop the ﬂow of blood. His condition is called sickle cell [anemia].  

7. Dr. Max Shelby is a physician who treats carcinomas and sarcomas. He is a/an [oncologist].

8. Bill had difﬁculty stopping the bleeding from a cut on his face while shaving. He knew his medication caused him to have decreased platelets, or a low [thrombocyte] count, and that probably was the reason his blood was not clotting very well.

9. Dr. Susan Parker told Paul that his condition would improve with treatment in a few weeks. She said his [prognosis] is excellent and he can expect total recovery.

10. After ﬂeeing the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001, Mrs. Jones had many problems with her job, her husband, and her family relationships. She went to see a [psychiatrist], who prescribed drugs to treat her depression.

instructions.instructions: Select from the terms listed below to complete the sentences that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Ms. Brody had a cough and fever. Her doctor instructed her to go to the  [radiology/pathology/hematology] department for a chest x-ray examination.

2. After she gave birth to her fourth child, Ms. Thompson had problems holding her urine (a condition known as urinary incontinence). She made an appointment with a  [urologist/gastroenterologist/pathologist] to evaluate her condition.

3. Dr. Monroe told a new mother she had lost much blood during delivery of her child. She had 
 [anemia/leukocytosis/adenitis] and needed a blood transfusion immediately.

4. Mr. Preston was having chest pain during his morning walks. He made an appointment to discuss his new symptom with a [cardiologist/nephrologist/neurologist].

5. After my skiing accident, Dr. Curtin suggested  [arthroscopy/cystoscopy/biopsy] to visually examine my swollen, painful knee.

instructions.instructions: Select the correct term to complete each sentence.
